studies.title: Ephesians
studies.description:
Ephesians is the "go-to" book in the New Testament for an understanding of God's sovereignty in salvation by grace, and therefore it shares much in common with Paul's other masterwork: Romans.

Paul wrote this letter while enduring his first Roman imprisonment in house arrest. As Roman guards stood watch, Paul penned a powerful letter to forestall an apostasy, a falling away, in a large church in a leading city of a powerful empire, a city renown for its wealth and fleshly indulgence.

Life in Ephesus was similar to life in major Western cities today. Many of the same temptations to depart the faith are tugging at the hearts of 21st-century believers as they were for the 1st-century believers in Ephesus, which makes this letter imperative to understand now. Pastor Steve will dissect the letter's powerful theology and practical advice for the Christian family in his usual in-depth, verse-by-verse approach.  

New lessons are posted most weeks. To attend the study live, please visit our Ephesians Event page.

studies.title: 2Timothy
1Timothy
studies.description:
Paul's ministry to the Gentiles took him throughout the known world, and along the way he collected men who desired to minister with him. One of those men was a young teacher and pastor named Timothy who stayed behind in Ephesus after Paul moved on. Later Paul wrote two letters to this young pastor encouraging him in the face of dissension and false teachers. 

Despite assaults from various critics over the centuries, Paul's advice to Timothy has stood the test of time proving itself to be an indispensable manual both for church leaders and congregations. Paul's words can be difficult at times, because his teaching exposes our pride, rebellion and selfishness, yet Paul is characteristically patient, loving and committed to delivering the truth no matter how it is received.

studies.title: Daniel
Ruth 2016
studies.description:
The Book of Ruth is classically described as a love story or a story of redemption. Though these descriptions are not wrong, they are incomplete.

The story of Ruth is a story of woman in need of grace and a man who is willing to extend it. It is also a footnote to the story of Judges and the times when Israel did what was right in its own eyes. Finally, the book of Ruth is properly understood to be a book of eschatology – a prophetic picture of God's plan for Israel and the Church. The literal events of the story foreshadow and explain God's redemption of a disobedient Israel and the opportunity for the Gentile world to share in Israel's promises.

This course is an updated, all-new presentation of our earlier study of Ruth. Pastor Armstrong teaches both the redemption storyline and the end times story line side by side through the entire book. Join us for an entirely unique and insightful explanation of this precious book of scripture.

studies.title: Judges
studies.description:
Join Pastor Armstrong for an in-depth study of the book of Judges.

Though few Christians study the book end to end, most recognize the book's iconic characters, including Samson, Gideon, and Deborah. Judges bridges the 300-year period between Moses and Joshua and the kings of Israel, when every tribe of Israel acted as nation unto itself. This is a book filled with heros, villains, love, war, miracles and God's grace. No wonder the book of Judges is a favorite source for classic Sunday school stories.

studies.title: 1Samuel
Revelation
studies.description:
Our authoritative, completely-revised 34-lesson study of end times in the book of Revelation is here! 

Many Christians consider Revelation to be a mysterious and even frightening book of scripture. Some avoid studying it, and among those who do try, many find it confusing. Why does the book confound so many and give rise to so many conflicting interpretations? The answer: because it's the final book of the Bible.

The Bible with its 66 books can be compared to a novel having 66 chapters. Like a novel, the storyline builds from front to back, with the characters, themes and plot elements introduced early and developed across many chapters. Obviously, the Bible doesn't read like most novels, but it was intended to be understood as a single work, and it did have a single Author.

Now consider what would happen if you selected a novel from the shelves of your local bookstore and decided to read only the final chapter. How much of that final chapter would you understand?  Most likely, you would be thoroughly confused. Naturally, only after reading the entire book would the final chapter make any sense.

Likewise, we could see Revelation as the final chapter in God's 66-chapter novel called the Bible. In the same way we must read a novel cover to cover before understanding it properly, so must Bible students have an understanding of the Bible's first 65 books before they can truly understand the final book of Revelation.

Under these circumstances, a verse-by-verse teaching of Revelation would be a challenging endeavor. How do you teach the last chapter in a novel when you can't be sure your audience has studied the first 65 books? The answer is simple: you teach them the entire Bible!

Consequently, our Revelation study examines not only the 22 chapters of John's vision, it also covers relevant sections of Genesis, Exodus, Deuteronomy, Leviticus, Ruth, Kings and Chronicles, Job, the Psalms, Daniel, Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, all the minor prophets, the Gospels and the Epistles. Virtually every book of the Bible is consulted during our 34-hour course, leading many VBVM students to say that our Revelation study is an attempt to teach the entire Bible in a single class. We know no other way to do it!

Simply put, there is no better study of end times than the VBVM International study of Revelation.

Our book of Revelation Bible study comes complete with MP3 audio teaching, complete PDF study notes (over 200,000 words!), and full color visual aids for projection or black and white visual aids for printing. Use all the materials to study for yourself or to teach the class to others.

Also, you can experience this same content complete with the visual aids as videos. More videos will be added each week until the entire study is available (expected to be complete by the end of 2015).

studies.title: The Gospel of John
Hebrews
studies.description:
Perhaps the most enigmatic epistle of the New Testament, the book of Hebrews confronts the reader with foundational Christian doctrines framed for an audience steeped in Jewish law and tradition. Perhaps this explains why present-day Christians often find this book confusing or even misleading.

We will peel back the layers of this complex and rich letter in typical VBVMI style: looking for scripture's common threads while appreciating the cultural and historical nuances that distinguish this letter.

This is an all-new edition of our Hebrews study, replacing our older study with new material and insight.

studies.title: Serving a Risen Lord - Easter 2016
First Corinthians
studies.description:
Paul's first letter to the church in Corinth is addressed to a church rife with sexual immorality, pagan worship and vestiges of Greek cultural influence. The letter combines extreme patience with firm correction as the Apostle pleads with the believers in Corinth to set aside the fleshly, sinful practices of their earlier lives and chart a new course as Christians.

Along the way, Paul contends with various doctrines, heresies and church practices including the misuse of spiritual gifts, eternal rewards for believers, treatment of the physical body, rules for marriage and divorce, and numerous other hot topics - for both the church then and today.

This version of First Corinthians replaces our previous study and is updated with new material and application.

studies.title: The Book of Romans
studies.description:
Paul's letter to the Romans is widely acknowledged to be the single most important theological essay ever written. Romans is literally loaded with essential Christian doctrine, and no Bible education is complete without a thorough examination of this book. Martin Luther commended every Christian to memorize Romans word-for-word, and though we may never reach this goal, we can certainly give ourselves to understanding its wisdom.

The Book of Romans reads like a course in systematic Christian theology, and it holds the keys to understanding a long list of fundamental Christian doctrines and beliefs, including soteriology (the doctrine of salvation), harmartiology (the doctrine of sin), Israelology (the doctrine of Israel), election, predestination, sanctification, and many other important truths.

The study was taught at Wayside Chapel in San Antonio, Texas in 2009.

Please note the first class meeting of Romans (Lesson 1A) experienced technical difficulties leading to a poor quality recording, but all remaining lessons are unaffected.

studies.title: Genesis
Acts of the Apostles
studies.description:
The Acts of the Apostles is the only narrative found in the New Testament apart from the Gospels, and it tells the compelling story of how the Lord grew and guided the early Church.

Some have suggested the book should be called the Acts of the Spirit, and truly every book of Scripture could bear that title. Nevertheless, Luke's account is squarely focused on the lives and work of men, who were striving to follow the Lord in the difficult work of establishing the faith. Can there be a more important study for any Christian desiring to follow in the Apostles' footsteps?

This study was taught from 2010-2011 in San Antonio, Texas.

studies.title: Nehemiah
studies.description: As God restores His people to a place of fellowship, He brings leaders to inspire, guide and direct the people into serving God truly. Nehemiah is a study of how God accomplishes this important step of restoring and growing His children.

studies.title: Exodus
studies.description:
This study follows the story of Moses and the people of Israel beginning with their days as slaves in Egypt, to the call of Moses and the plagues of God's judgment, to their trek through the desert, and ending with their encampment around Mt. Horeb. In addition to examining the text of scripture, the study will review Egyptian history, ancient custom and practice, and the meaning of the Law and Tabernacle.

As usual, the book is better than the movie!

studies.title: Galatians
The Gospel of Luke
studies.description:
A verse-by-verse study of the Gospel of Luke. The study examines not just the storyline of Luke's Gospel but its major themes as well. This is an in-depth and probing examination of Jesus' teaching and ministry, offering the serious student an intriguing opportunity to learn God's Word where it matters most: the telling of the Gospel story.

Chapters 1-12 were recorded from July 2005 through June 2006 from the pulpit at Living Word Fellowship in San Antonio, Texas. Chapters 13-24 were recorded from January through September 2007 at Wayside Chapel in San Antonio, Texas.

studies.title: 2John & 3John
studies.description:
John's second letter is a mere 13 verses. Don't let that fool you. It offers multiple points of spiritual wisdom every Christian should understand. His third letter is only 15 verses, but unites two essential themes: the importance of supporting what is good while correctly what is wrong in the church. 

Each study is a single lesson of teaching, so why not download and listen to each? You won't find a more compact study of spiritual truth anywhere.

studies.title: Ezra
studies.description:
Following the Babylonian captivity, the Lord directed a remnant of Israel to return to the land and rebuild the city of Jerusalem. The nation had neither king nor high priest nor prophet, but the Lord gave them a scribe named Ezra. In Ezra 7:10 we learn that Ezra was a man who "had set his heart to study the law of the LORD and to practice it, and to teach His statutes and ordinances in Israel."

Through Ezra, the Lord restored His people following a period of judgment, and we can learn a lot from Israel's experience as we study this book in depth and verse-by-verse.

studies.title: Epistle of Jude
studies.description:
Few studies of scripture combine so few verses with so much controversy and mystery as the book of Jude. The letter is only 25 verses, but despite it’s short length, it’s one of the least often studied books of scripture. The letter invites wonder and even confusion because of it’s frequent references to extra-Biblical material, and the tone of the letter is distinctly apocalyptic, though it never attempts to explain future events in detail. 

In the end, the letter is constructed as a stern warning to the church, one that would be particularly applicable in the last days, making it a letter with a lot of "bang for the buck."

studies.title: God and Man - Easter 2013
studies.description:
Was Jesus really God and did God really die and go down to Hell? These questions are central to beliefs of orthodox Christianity. In his Easter 2013 message, God and Man, Pastor Armstrong recounts a conversation he had with two members of the Jehovah's Witnesses religion and demonstrates why these questions make all the difference between the salvation offered by the Gospel of Jesus Christ and trusting in a false powerless message.

The teaching was delivered to Oak Hill Bible Church in Austin, Texas, on Easter Sunday, 2013.

studies.title: The Adulterous Woman - A Teaching from John 8
studies.thumbnailAltText: The Adulterous Woman - A Teaching from John 8

studies.title: Jesus & The Blind Man
studies.description:
In John's gospel, Jesus comes upon a man born blind and performs a unique healing unlike any other found in the Biblical record. It brings a number of surprises, none greater than in the way we discover ourselves in the story. This is an evangelistic message that includes a call to the listener to believe the Gospel of Jesus Christ.


This lesson was presented on May 18, 2008, at Oak Hill Bible Church in Austin, Texas.

studies.title: The Samaritan Woman
Isaiah
The Sovereignty of God
studies.description:
This series is a challenging 7-part teaching on the nature and impact of God's sovereignty in major spiritual issues in our lives, including prayer, wealth, health, world events, evangelism and the impact of the Word of God itself. Much has been said and written about the role of God in His creation and in the lives of men; now hear what the scriptures say about it.

This series also includes an examination of the disturbing trend in the church to leave the word of God behind in the pulpit and preach a false gospel of prosperity.

studies.title: The Letter of James
studies.description:
James' letter to the church is rich in exhortation and encouragement. James wrote to Jewish believers, who comprised the bulk of believers in his day, but the content of the letter is timeless and timely.


James teaches how believers are to face trials and how we should seek to live out God's word. He denounces favoritism in the church and an unhealthy view of money. Finally, he calls all believers to pursue their sanctification with an urgency and passion often missing in the lives of believers, including believers today.


The study was taught at Oak Hill Bible Church during Summer 2010.

studies.title: First Letter of Peter
studies.description: A verse-by-verse teaching through the Apostle Peter's first letter. Peter's letter is a practical and frank letter, focused less on explaining complex Christian doctrine and more on exhorting readers to apply what they know concerning Christ and God's word in their lives as they face adversity and trials.

studies.title: Seeking Fame for Christ
studies.description: As followers of Christ, we seek to bring attention to Jesus, but did you know it's possible to seek fame for Christ in a wrong way? Learn how Jesus' earthly brothers tried to do that in this guest preaching taken from chapter 7 of the Gospel of John and delivered at the Lighthouse Christian Fellowship in Las Vegas, Nevada, on June 3, 2007.

studies.title: Avoiding Balaam
studies.description: When a church loses a pastor, the desire to fill the pulpit quickly can tempt the church leadership to cut corners and select a man who promises the world, literally. How can the church's leadership ensure they find God's man to lead them? We can learn something from the story of Balaam in Numbers 22.

studies.title: Moses’ Three Objections
studies.description:
Moses received one of the greatest calls into ministry ever recorded in the Bible, yet when he first heard it, did Moses embrace his calling enthusiastically? Not exactly. Study Moses' three objections to accepting God's call on his life, and learn how you might be raising those same objections in the face of your own call to serve God. This teaching is taken from Exodus 4.

This lesson was presented on June 28, 2008, at Parkhills Baptist Church in San Antonio, Texas.

studies.title: Pride and Avarice
studies.description:
This is a single verse-by-verse teaching through the first chapter of the Book of Haggai. God calls men to serve Him and not themselves, yet the nation of Israel lost sight of this calling as they became discouraged during the rebuilding of the second temple after returning from captivity. In today's culture preaching pursuit of Self, the lessons of Haggai are especially timely.

This lesson was presented on November 18, 2007 at the Oak Hill Bible Church in Austin, Texas.

studies.title: Obedience as Worship
studies.description:
This is a verse-by-verse teaching taken from 1Chronicles and the life of King David. Worship is much more than singing praise to God once a week in church. First and foremost, worship is a life of obedience to God's word. Learn the importance of obedience as worship in the story of David's efforts to retrieve the Ark of the Covenant from a small town and return it to Jerusalem.

This lesson was presented on April 27, 2008 at Oak Hill Bible Church in Austin, Texas.

studies.title: Friend to a King
studies.description: Years after King David establishes a covenant with Saul's son, Jonathan, a curious scene takes place in 2Samuel 9. Study that scene and its eternal spiritual signficance in this guest preaching called "Friend To A King," delivered at Thunderbolt Baptist Church in Savannah, Georgia, on October 14, 2007.

studies.title: Simon’s Confession
studies.description:
Simon the Magician was the big man on campus in Samaria. He performed his magic act regularly and commanded a sizeable audience everytime. The crowd never suspected that Simon's power was not of God, until God's power arrived in the form of the evangelist Philip. Like Simon, many people can fool the world - and even themselves, but God's Spirit will reveal the truth in all of us sooner or later.

This teaching contrasts the false conversion of Simon with the true conversion of a pilgram from Ethiopia, taken from Acts 8.

studies.title: The Wise Men of Babylon
studies.description: Everyone has heard of the "three wise men" or magi that visited the Christ child. These strange men from the East are depicted in every Nativity scene and are mentioned in numerous Christmas carols. But what does the Bible really say about who these men were and why they visited the Jewish Messiah bearing gifts? Listen to our Christmas Eve message and learn the answers.

studies.title: The Book of Colossians
studies.description:
A study through Paul's letter to Colosse. Paul's letter opens with one of the most powerful testimonies of Christ's glory and the gospel, and it includes important warnings on legalism and humanistic thought, encouragement for godly living, and even some interesting insights into the early church fathers.

Note: This study also includes materials for leading a small group study. Be sure to download the Listening Guides and Teaching Guides with Lesson 1A.

studies.title: The Book of Jonah
studies.description:
JonahAn 8-week study through the story of the Old Testament prophet Jonah. Despite the universal recognition of Jonah as the man swallowed alive by a giant fish, few Christians truly understand the story's details and spiritual meaning.

This course examines the events of the Book of Jonah verse-by-verse, with an eye toward it's ultimate prophetic significance.

studies.title: Elijah’s Disappointment
studies.description:
The northern kingdom of Israel suffered through many evil kings, none worse than Ahab and his wife Jezebel. Into this evil kingdom God called Elijah to stand against the sin and apostacy of the northern tribes. Elijah's testimony of God's authority and power to the disobedient tribes provided a test of faith and obedience - but the real test was found in Elijah's heart.

This lesson was presented on June 15, 2008, at Lighthouse Christian Fellowship in Las Vegas, Nevada.

studies.title: Look Up - Easter 2011
studies.description:
During their forty years of wandering in the desert, the Israelites tested God many times with their unbelief. Near the end of their wandering, God brings a different kind of judgment upon the camp of Israel that threatened to wipe them out. Finally, God intervened through Moses to show His grace.

See how this interesting account has a special link to our Easter celebration, based on Jesus' own words in John 3.

This preaching was delivered to Oak Hill Bible Church in Austin, Texas, on Easter Sunday 2011.

studies.title: Restoring God’s People
studies.description:
Most of us have experienced discipline from our earthly father, but what about the discipline of our Heavenly Father? Scripture tells us that God also disciplines those He loves, yet few Christians take time to study and understand how God applies discipline in our lives. This study offers an in-depth appreciation of how the Father disciplines and then restores His children.

The study examines events in the history of the nation of Israel, when it received the Father's discipline as they entered into Babylonian captivity and eventually were restored to the land. The study examines passages from 1 & 2 Kings, 1 & 2 Chronicles, Ezra and Nehemiah.

studies.title: Proofs for the Resurrection
studies.description: Everything we believe about the life, teachings and significance of Jesus of Nazareth hinges on our view of the Resurrection accounts. The Resurrection account in the Gospels is the most compelling evidence for the deity of Jesus. This teaching offers a survey of the evidence presented in support of the eyewitness accounts. This lesson was presented on Easter 2009 at Oak Hill Bible Church in Austin, Texas.

studies.title: Parables of Jesus
studies.description:
Many of Jesus' most profound teachings were presented in riddles called parables. The meaning of His teaching was cloaked because (as Jesus Himself stated) only certain people were intended to understand the meaning. By the revelation of the Holy Spirit, believers are able to understand the meaning of His parables, and this series explores several of Jesus' more famous parables for "those who have ears to hear."

The notes for this series can be found as part of our Luke study.

studies.title: The Great Exchange
